verses.roman:
sarpa-caurāgni-vidyudbhyaḥ
kṣut-tṛd-vyādhy-ādibhir nṛpa
pañcatvam ṛcchate jantur
bhuṅkta ārabdha-karma tat

synonyms: sarpa—from snakes; caura—thieves; agni—fire; vidyudbhyaḥ—and lightning; kṣut—from hunger; tṛṭ—thirst; vyādhi—disease; ādibhiḥ—and other agents; nṛpa—O King; pañcatvam—death; ṛcchate—obtains; jantuḥ—the conditioned living entity; bhuṅkte—he enjoys; ārabdha—already created by his past work; karma—the fruitive reaction; tat—that.
translation: When a conditioned soul is killed by snakes, thieves, fire, lightning, hunger, disease or anything else, he is experiencing the reaction to his own past work.

purport.content: According to Śrīla Viśvanātha Cakravartī Ṭhākura, King Parīkṣit obviously was not suffering the reaction of past karma. As a great devotee he was personally brought back home, back to Godhead, by the Lord.
